name: Senator Pat Geary
description: A corrupt and self-important U.S. Senator who becomes entangled with the Corleone family in The Godfather Part II.

content.title: Background
content.body: Senator Pat Geary is an ambitious U.S. Senator from Nevada who holds considerable influence in the political arena during the early 1950s. He is depicted as a man who enjoys the trappings of power and is eager to exploit his position for personal gain. Geary is shown to have a penchant for corruption, selectively targeting the Corleone family initially as a pawn to serve his broader interests. He is charismatic yet deeply insecure, which fuels his behavior and decision-making. His political career is marked by efforts to consolidate his power, partly driven by the desire to project his authority beyond the Senate chambers.

content.title: Personality
content.body: Geary is portrayed as self-aggrandizing and pompous, often intoxicated with his own sense of importance. Despite this, he can be cunning and manipulative when it suits his needs. His fragile ego, especially when confronted or challenged, leads him to unpredictable and sometimes reckless actions. Though outwardly confident, Geary's arrogance disguises a deep vulnerability to embarrassment and loss of face, which several characters in the film exploit. He is also shown to be easily swayed by flattery and intimidation.

content.title: Story Role
content.body: In The Godfather Part II, Senator Geary represents the intersection of political power and organized crime. Initially hostile to the Corleones, he coerces Michael Corleone into a humiliating arrangement. However, after a calculated retaliation by the Corleones, Geary is reduced to a compliant ally, illustrating the family's dominance over political institutions. His role serves as a vehicle to demonstrate Michael Corleone's strategic acumen in extending his criminal empire’s control into legitimate political spheres. Geary's downfall exemplifies the corruptibility of political figures when confronted by organized crime’s power.

content.title: Relationships
content.body: Geary’s most significant relationship in the narrative is with Michael Corleone, who manipulates the Senator to serve the family's interests. Their dynamic moves from adversarial to one of reluctant partnership. Geary also interacts with Michael’s associates, including Tom Hagen, and is intimidated by the Corleone family’s unfaltering presence. Additionally, Geary’s wife, though not prominently featured, is implied to share in his social status. His relationships exemplify how political figures are enmeshed in the complex web of power and corruption that defines the film’s universe.

content.title: Abilities/Skills
content.body: Senator Geary wields political influence and understands the workings of government bureaucracy. He has the skills to pass legislation, leverage his senatorial authority, and manipulate public institutions to his advantage. However, his inability to grasp the full extent of the Corleones’ power and his personal arrogance ultimately undermine his effectiveness. His communication skills allow him to maintain a public façade of respectability, though he lacks the strategic depth that characters like Michael Corleone possess.
